description:
Didymella exigua CBS 183.55 is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Didymella, which is part of the Ascomycota phylum. This species was first isolated and described in 1955, with the culture collection number CBS 183.55.

Didymella exigua is a saprophytic fungus, meaning it primarily feeds on dead or decaying organic matter. It is commonly found in soil and can also be associated with plant materials, such as leaf litter or crop residues.

Morphologically, D. exigua produces small, black, pseudothecial ascomata (fruiting bodies) on the substrate. The asci (spore-bearing structures) within the ascomata are cylindrical and contain eight ascospores. The ascospores are typically ellipsoidal to fusiform in shape and are septate, meaning they have one or more transverse divisions.

Genetically, D. exigua has been identified and characterized based on DNA sequence analysis, particularly of the internal transcribed spacer (ITS) regions of the ribosomal DNA (rDNA). This information can be used for taxonomic identification and to study the phylogenetic relationships within the genus Didymella.

Overall, Didymella exigua CBS 183.55 is a saprobic fungal species that plays a role in the decomposition of organic matter in various ecological niches.
